definition: To gather or build up over time.
examples: Dust can accumulate under the bed.
She accumulated points through steady practice.

extra.memory_tip: Accumulate = add a little at a time until it mounts up.

definition: To make a problem or situation worse; to annoy someone.
examples: Scratching will aggravate the rash.
Loud chatter aggravated the librarian.

extra.memory_tip: Aggravate = add gravity to the problem.

definition: To protect from loss or waste; to use carefully.
examples: Turn off lights to conserve energy.
We conserved water during the drought.

extra.memory_tip: Conserve = serve the future by saving now.

definition: To make something dirty, unsafe, or impure by adding a harmful substance.
examples: Oil spills can contaminate beaches.
Do not contaminate samples with bare hands.

extra.memory_tip: Con-taminate = add ‘bad stuff’ and it’s not the same.

definition: To make or become smaller, fewer, or less important.
examples: The noise diminished after midnight.
We must not diminish anyone’s effort.

definition: Extreme or severe; likely to have a strong effect.
examples: They took drastic steps to cut costs.
A drastic change in weather surprised hikers.

definition: Spending or using more than necessary; very fancy or excessive.
examples: They threw an extravagant party.
Buying a new phone now would be extravagant.

definition: Careful about spending; using money or resources wisely.
examples: A frugal shopper waits for sales.
They cooked a frugal but tasty meal.

extra.memory_tip: Frugal = fewer gulps of your budget.

definition: Something that makes another substance dirty or not pure.
examples: Filters remove impurities from water.
Gold is measured by how few impurities it has.

extra.memory_tip: Impurity = ‘in’ the pure stuff is something else.

examples: The hikers were in peril during the blizzard.
Ignoring safety rules puts others in peril.

definition: Continuing forever or for a very long time without stopping.
examples: They lived in perpetual daylight near midsummer.
His perpetual optimism lifted the team.

definition: A supply of materials, money, or skills that can be used; something useful for a purpose.
examples: Clean water is a vital resource.
The library is a great learning resource.

extra.memory_tip: Resource = source you can rely on.

definition: To use or put in place of something else; a person or thing used instead of another.
examples: You can substitute yoghurt for cream. (verb)
The substitute taught maths today. (noun)

definition: To keep something going; to support; to suffer (a loss or injury).
examples: Trees help sustain life on Earth.
The player sustained a minor injury.
It’s vital to drink water on hot days.
Trust is a vital part of teamwork.
